raw_text:
Israeli economy picking up pace
 
 Israel's economy is forecast to grow by 4.2% in 2004 as it continues to emerge from a three-year recession.
 
 The main driver of the faster-than-expected expansion has been exports, with tourism seeing a strong rebound, the statistical office said. The economy is benefiting from a quieter period in Palestinian-Israeli violence and a pick-up in global demand for technology products. The outlook is better than it has been for a number of years, analysts said.
 
 Many companies have focused on cost cutting and greater efficiency, while the government has been trying to trim public spending and push through reforms. The growth figures come about despite a strike earlier this year by about 400,000 public sector worker which closed banks, hospitals, postal services and transport facilities. Growth did slow in the second half, but only slightly. Exports for the year rose by 14%, while tourist revenues were up by 30%. Imports gained by 13%, signalling that domestic demand has picked up again. In 2003, imports declined by 1.8%. In 2003, the economy expanded by 1.3%
llama3.2:1b: Israel's economy is forecast to grow by 4.2% in 2004 due to a strong rebound in exports and improved global demand for technology products.
The growth was driven mainly by tourism, with an increase of 30%, despite a strike earlier this year that affected public services.
llama3.2:3b: Israel's economy is forecast to grow by 4.2% in 2004 due to a strong rebound in tourism and exports, driven by global demand for technology products, with many companies focusing on cost cutting and efficiency reforms.
gemma2:2b: Israel's economy is forecast to grow 4.2% in 2004, driven primarily by strong exports and a rebound in tourism.
The growth is positive despite a public sector strike earlier this year, which caused temporary disruptions.
Domestic demand is increasing as evidenced by rising imports.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The Israeli economy is expected to grow at a pace of 4.2% in 2004, driven by exports and technology products.
Growth has been affected by an ongoing conflict in Palestine-Israel.
Companies are focusing on cost-cutting and efficiency while the government aims to cut public spending and implement reforms.
Despite economic challenges, growth figures for 2003 showed a modest increase.
In 2004, imports were down 1.8% compared to 2003, while tourism revenue rose by 30%.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Israel's 2004 economy is forecast to grow by 4.2%, driven by stronger exports and tourism following a three-year recession.
Growth comes despite a public sector strike in the second half of the year that slowed imports but not overall demand.
Exports increased by 14% and tourist revenues rose by 30%.
qwen2.5:3b: Israeli economy is forecast to grow by 4.2% in 2004 as it emerges from a recession.
Key drivers include faster-than-expected export growth and tourism rebound due to reduced Palestinian-Israeli violence and increased global tech demand.
While public sector strikes affected some sectors, overall outlook is positive compared to recent years.
Exports rose 14%, tourist revenues climbed 30%, and domestic demand strengthened.
opencoder:1.5b: The output of this code will be a concise and clear summary of the text, focusing on the main points and details discussed in the input.
smollm:1.7b: The Israeli economy is expected to grow by 4.2% in 2004 as it recovers from a three-year recession.
The main driver of this growth has been exports, which have seen a strong rebound, while tourism also saw a significant increase.
The outlook for the economy is better than it has been for a number of years, with many companies focusing on cost cutting and greater efficiency.
However, the government has been trying to trim public spending and push through reforms in an effort to boost growth further.
The strike by about 400,000 public sector workers earlier this year did slow down the economy slightly, but only slightly.
Exports for the year rose by 14% while tourist revenues were up by 30%.
Imports gained by 13%, indicating that domestic demand has picked up again.
deepseek-r1:1.5b: Israel's economy grew at a robust 4.2% in 2004 as it recovered from a three-year recession.
The main driver was exports, particularly from the Palestinian region, benefiting from a quieter period in Palestinian violence and global tech demand.
The government focused on cost-cutting and reforms, though a strike closed several sectors.
Growth was steady during the second half of 2004, with tourism and imports returning to higher levels than usual.
In 2003, imports declined by 1.8%, while growth was modest compared to previous years.
tinyllama:1.1b: Israel's economy is expected to grow by 4.2% in 2004 as it emerges from a three-year recession driven by exports and an increase in tourism, according to the Statistical Office.
The main driver of this expansion has been an uptick in global demand for technology products due to the pickup in Palestinian-Israeli violence and renewed international investment in Israeli firms.
Many companies have focused on cost cutting and greater efficiency, while the government has been pushing through reforms aimed at boosting the economy.
Despite a strike earlier this year by about 400,000 public sector workers, exports continued to climb in the second half of the year, with imports only slightly decreasing.
Tourist revenues were up by 30%, signaling that domestic demand has picked up once more.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Israel's economy is predicted to grow by over 4.2% in 2004, driven primarily by increased tourism and a pick-up in global demand for technology products.
The country's main drivers are tourism which saw a strong rebound following a period of conflict, and the pick-up in global demand for technology products.
Despite concerns about economic slowdown during the height of Palestinian-Israeli violence and a resurgence in international trade, analysts predict an improved outlook for the Israeli economy.
phi:2.7b: Israel's economy is forecast to grow by 4.2% in 2004 as it emerges from a three-year recession due to increased exports and tourism.
The growth figures come despite a brief strike by public sector workers, with companies focusing on efficiency and the government pushing reforms.
Imports have picked up again and domestic demand has improved.
In 2003, imports declined but overall, the economy is expected to improve in 2004.
orca-mini:3b: Israel's economy is expected to grow by 4.2% in 2004 due to a strong rebound in tourism and higher exports.
The government has been working to reduce public spending and promote reforms while many companies have focused on efficiency gains.
Despite a strike earlier this year, the economy saw growth in both the first and second halves of the year.
Exports grew by 14% while imports gained by 13%, indicating that domestic demand has picked up again.
hermes3:3b: Israel economic growth: 4.2% (2004), exports driving; Palestinian-Israeli violence reducing; technology demand boosting; cost cutting & efficiency by companies, government reforms.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Israel's economy is forecast to grow by 4.2% in 2004, driven by exports, tourism, and increased global demand for technology products.
The growth outlook is better than in recent years, despite a strike affecting 400,000 public sector workers earlier in the year.
Exports grew 14% and tourist revenues were up 30%, while imports gained 13%.
Domestic demand picked up as imports declined 1.8% in 2003, reflecting a more positive economic landscape for Israel.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Israel's economy is expected to grow by 4.2% in 2004, emerging from a three-year recession.
The main drivers are strong export growth and a rebound in tourism, aided by reduced Israeli-Palestinian violence and increased global demand for technology.
Companies have focused on cost-cutting and efficiency, while the government has pursued spending cuts and reforms.
Despite a major public sector strike, exports rose by 14%, tourism revenues by 30%, and imports by 13%, indicating revived domestic demand.
This follows 1.3% growth in 2003, when imports had declined.
stablelm2:1.6b: Israel's economy is expected to grow by 4.2% in 2015 due to exports and a recovery in tourism after a three-year recession.
The growth is mainly driven by exports and a quieter period of Palestinian- Israeli violence.
Domestic demand has also increased, offsetting the strike that affected public sector workers earlier this year.
Imports gained, while tourist revenues rose, with overall imports increasing by 1%.
In the third quarter, the economy expanded by 1.3%, despite a decline in the second half.
granite3.1-dense:2b: Israel's economy is projected to expand by 4.2% in 2004, marking a significant recovery from its three-year recession.
This growth is primarily fueled by increased exports and a resurgence in tourism, attributed to diminished Palestinian-Israeli violence and heightened global demand for technology products.

Despite a 400,000-strong public sector strike earlier this year that temporarily halted banking, healthcare, postal services, and transport, growth slowed only marginally in the second half of 2003 compared to 1.3% expansion in 2003.
Exports surged by 14%, while tourist revenues increased by 30%.
Imports rose by 13%, indicating a revival in domestic demand, which had previously decreased by 1.8% in 2003.
